table-wrap.anchoringText: As there are sections in the wells where the density log can be adversely affected by the hole conditions, a second HRA was performed (labelled HRA_Tagged_II in the log displays) using only the interpreted total porosity (which has been compensated for ‘bad hole’) and the deep resistivity. The HRA classes in both analyses are represented by different colours. A total of 4 classes (Dark blue; yellow; light green and light blue) are mapped in the second HRA analysis. Table 1 below shows the RQ class graded for the second HRA analysis which only uses interpreted total porosity and deep resistivity logs. A quick comparison is then possible between wells to understand the RQ variability.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: RQ class graded by quality of porosity

tr.td: HRA CLASS II distribution over perforation depths
3a (100% Yellow – Tight; Non-reservoir) 3b (~50% Deep Blue - Best reservoir; rest Non-reservoir)
~50% Deep Blue in Best reservoir class; rest Non-reservoir – Yellow and Light Green class
Some possible fractures across 3a towards the top (most of 3a tight zone). A high density of discontinuous own fractures and a few possible fractures towards the bottom tight interval of 3b.
Only a few discontinuous open fractures observed in the middle of 3b across tight interval.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Analysis of the summary in Table 3 indicates well N2 to be the most suitable in terms of RQ (especially perf 2b in terms of porosity and hydrocarbon saturation). However, well N3 is the best in terms of natural fracture development. Well N3 is also seen to be the best producer post stimulation and this seems to tie to the presence of high density discontinuous natural fractures (possibly enhanced post stimulation). Figure 6 shows an integrated log composite of well N2 with HRA and all input logs used as input to generate the HRA.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: RQ and related comparisons between the three wells in Lower Dolomite Formation

formatted-caption.caption-text: RQ and related comparisons between the three wells in Lower Dolomite Formation
